Expectation1: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation1: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: This morning, as I finished leading Fajr prayer, Brother Ahmed approached me, his face drawn with worry. “Imam, could I speak with you privately? It’s urgent—my family is falling apart.” I could see the desperation in his eyes, and I knew my role was to offer him guidance and comfort, especially when he needed it most. But as he spoke, my mind drifted to the envelope on my kitchen table—my only valid ID, which I’d forgotten to bring. Today is the only morning I can go home and get it before work, and without it, I can’t vote in tomorrow’s election. The community expects me to be present, to listen, to help. But as a citizen, I have a duty to participate in the election, and I can’t do that without my ID. My heart pounded as I weighed the needs of my congregant against my responsibility as a voter, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in on me.
